stem: A 24-year-old client is 2 days postpartum following a healthy delivery. She was discharged this morning but returns to the ED with a 'blinding headache.' Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute postpartum neurological threat.
Background: G1P1. No hypertension during pregnancy. Discharged 6 hours ago.
Assessment: Client is extremely agitated, photosensitive, and reporting 'flashes of light.'
Recommendation: Immediate magnesium protocol.

tabs.title: Postpartum Recovery Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Blood Pressure172/112 mmHgSevere HTN
Visual AssessmentScotoma (Flashes) notedCerebral Edema
Urine Dipstick3+ ProteinProteinuria
Reflexes4+ (Very Brisk) with ClonusImpending Seizure

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 172/112, HR 102, RR 22. Edema in ankles is 3+.

actionOptions.text: Initiate IV Magnesium Sulfate for seizure prophylaxis
Assess deep tendon reflexes and implement seizure precautions
Administer high-dose Naproxen for the headache
Encourage the client to pump breastmilk

rationale.correct: The client's symptoms (severe headache, elevated blood pressure, proteinuria, hyperreflexia with clonus, visual disturbances) are indicative of postpartum preeclampsia with severe features (c1). This condition can occur up to 6 weeks postpartum, even in women without a history of hypertension during pregnancy. The priority nursing actions are to initiate IV magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis (a1) and assess deep tendon reflexes while implementing seizure precautions (a2). Key parameters to monitor include blood pressure and mental status (p1), as well as headache intensity and vision changes (p2).
clinicalPearls: Postpartum preeclampsia/eclampsia can occur up to 6 weeks after delivery.
Magnesium sulfate is administered to prevent seizures, not primarily to lower blood pressure.
A severe headache, especially with visual disturbances, can be a sign of impending stroke in postpartum preeclampsia/eclampsia.

questionTrap.trap: Administering NSAIDs like Naproxen to treat the headache.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NSAIDs can worsen blood pressure in preeclamptic patients and mask neurological warning signs. Address the underlying hypertension and cerebral edema first.

mnemonic.title: Late-OB Pressure
mnemonic.expansion: L-Late onset. A-Agitated. T-Tense BP. E-Emergency Mag.
